descriptions:

**Title:** Health, Cognition, Family, and Employment among Men

**Abstract:**

This project aims to investigate how men's changing family and working lives influence their health and cognition. Despite men's higher premature mortality rate and significant preventable excess mortality, research has largely overlooked the social and economic factors contributing to these disparities. Our goal is to improve men's health and cognition by examining the complex relationships between men's family roles, labor market participation, and health outcomes. We will focus on young adulthood and midlife, disentangling selection and causality to identify cohort and period differences, the impact of the work-face interface, and the role of the male breadwinner model. Using Norwegian population data, including register, survey, and genetic data, we will examine health measures, employment patterns, and cognitive trajectories among 12,000+ men aged late teens to 69. By enhancing our understanding of these critical factors, we can develop targeted interventions to promote men's health, extend their potential, and advance gender equality.

Title: Health, Cognition, Family, and Employment among Men

This proposal seeks funding to investigate the complex relationships between men's changing family and working lives and their health and cognition. Despite higher premature mortality rates and significant preventable excess mortality among men, research has largely overlooked the social and economic factors contributing to these disparities. Our project aims to improve men's health and cognition by examining how increasing family roles, labour market participation, and societal contributions intersect with health and cognitive outcomes.

Using a unique combination of Norwegian population data, including register, survey, and genetic data, we will disentangle selection and causality to understand how men's health and cognition evolve across young adulthood and midlife. Our research will focus on cohort and period differences, the work-face interface, the male breadwinner model, and fathers' participation in childcare. With a sample size of over 12,000 men, our study will provide critical insights into the health and cognitive trajectories of men aged late teens to 36-69.

By shedding light on these complex relationships, our project will inform strategies to promote gender equality, enhance men's health and cognition, and extend their potential in society. We believe that this research has the potential to make a significant impact on men's health and well-being, and we look forward to the opportunity to conduct this important work.

Here is an abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Health, Cognition, Family, and Employment among Men

This project seeks to investigate the complex relationships between men's changing family and working lives and their health and cognition. Despite higher premature mortality rates and significant preventable excess mortality, men's health has received relatively little attention. This study aims to address this gender health disparity by examining how men's increasing family roles, enhancing labour market participation, and extended social contributions impact their health and cognition.

Using a mixed-methods approach, we will analyze Norwegian population data, including register, survey, and genetic data, to disentangle selection and causality. We will focus on men's health and cognition during young adulthood and midlife, exploring cohort and period differences, the work-face interface, the male breadwinner model, and fathers' participation in childcare. Our sample size of over 12,000 men, aged from late teens to 36-69, will provide a comprehensive understanding of men's health and cognitive trajectories.

By understanding the interplay between men's family, work, and health, this project aims to improve men's health and cognition, ultimately contributing to gender equality goals. The findings will inform policies and interventions that promote healthy lifestyles, enhance men's employment opportunities, and support their increasing family roles.
